pitch.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a marked out area of ground on which a sport is played
pitch.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: He ran the length of the pitch and scored.
Jack was on the pitch for his school in the Senior Cup Final.
pitch.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: a strong level of feeling about something or a high level of an activity or a quality
pitch.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The controversy reached such a pitch (=become so strong) that the paper devoted a whole page to it.
The goal roused the crowd to fever pitch (=a very excited level).
He screamed at her in a pitch of fury.
pitch.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: how high or low a note or other sound is
pitch.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Ultrasonic waves are at a higher pitch than the human ear can hear.
pitch.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: the ability of a musician to play or sing a note at exactly the correct level
pitch.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: the things someone says to persuade people to buy something, do something, or accept an idea
pitch.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: an aggressive salesman with a fast-talking sales pitch
He made his strongest pitch yet for standardized testing in schools.
pitch.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: a throw of the ball, or a way in which it can be thrown
pitch.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: His first pitch was high and wide.
pitch.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: a black sticky substance that is used on roofs, the bottoms of ships etc to stop water coming through
pitch.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: The night was as black as pitch (=very dark).
pitch.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: an up and down movement of a ship or an aircraft
pitch.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: the pitch and roll of the ship
pitch.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: the degree to which a roof slopes or the sloping part of a roof
pitch.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: the steep pitch of the roof
pitch.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: a place in a public area where someone goes to sell things or where an entertainer goes to perform
pitch.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: We found the boy at his usual pitch at the bottom of the Acropolis.
pitch.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to throw something with a lot of force, often aiming carefully
pitch.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: She crumpled up the page and pitched it into the fire.
pitch.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to aim and throw a ball in baseball
pitch.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Stanton pitched to two batters in the ninth inning.
pitch.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: if a ball pitches in cricket or golf, it hits the ground
pitch.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: to hit the ball in a high curve in golf
pitch.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: to make the ball hit the ground when you are bowling in cricket
pitch.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: to fall or be moved suddenly in a particular direction, or to make someone or something do this
pitch.translation[1].definitions[5].exam: She slipped and pitched forward onto the ground.
Without a seat belt, you can easily be pitched right through the windscreen.
pitch.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: if a ship or an aircraft pitches, it moves up and down in an uncontrolled way with the movement of the water or air
pitch.translation[1].definitions[7].defi: to set a speech, examination, explanation etc at a particular level of difficulty
pitch.translation[1].definitions[7].exam: Some questions were pitched too high for intermediate students.
You have to pitch your writing at the right level.
pitch something at a high level/the right level etc
pitch.translation[1].definitions[8].defi: to set prices at a particular level
pitch.translation[1].definitions[8].exam: Room rates are pitched at £69 for a single.
pitch.translation[1].definitions[9].defi: to aim a product at a particular type of organization, group of people etc, or to describe it in a particular way, in order to sell it
pitch.translation[1].definitions[9].exam: The new machine will be pitched at users in the hotel and air reservation business.
It is pitched as a cheaper alternative to other workstations.
pitch.translation[1].definitions[9].note: Pitch is usually passive in this meaning
pitch.translation[1].definitions[10].def: to try to persuade someone to do business with you, buy something etc
pitch.translation[1].definitions[10].exa: Booksellers are keen to pitch for school business.
For many companies, pitching to investors has become almost a full-time job.
pitch.translation[1].definitions[11].def: if you pitch your voice or another sound at a particular level, the sound is produced at that level
pitch.translation[1].definitions[11].exa: Her voice is pitched a little too high.
pitch.translation[1].definitions[12].exa: The roof pitches sharply to the rear of the house.
pitch.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: what a sales person says about a product to persuade people to buy it
pitch.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: an attempt by an ADVERTISING AGENCY to persuade a company to use its services to advertise a product
pitch.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: a place in a public area where a street trader goes to sell things
pitch.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: to set prices at a particular level
pitch.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: Prices for the new trucks are pitched very competitively.
pitch.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: to try to make a business agreement, or to sell something in a particular way
pitch.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: sales reps pitching the latest gadgets
The resort is being pitched as a conference venue.
The luxury clothing retailer has invited a number of agencies to pitch for its estimated £1.5 million international business.
